channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hero’s Welcome for Zelensky in Washington Lifts Mood in Kyiv
item.description: Ukrainians said they hoped their president’s appeal to Congress would keep American aid flowing, while Moscow cast the visit as a publicity stunt. The U.S. said North Korea is arming Russian mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine after he addressed members of Congress in Washington.

item.title: In Bakhmut, a Food Stand Stays Open Despite the War
item.description: Despite all the shelling, and with no electricity, one snack shop is still serving the soldiers and citizens who have stayed in Bakhmut, Ukraine, a pivotal battleground in the war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: How Does Pompeii Maintain Its Ruins? Hungry Sheep.
item.description: The archaeological park of Pompeii has found a low-tech way to prevent the site from being overrun by vegetation: hungry sheep.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaspare de Martino grazing his sheep in an unexcavated section of the Pompeii archaeological site.

item.title: Israel’s New Government Pushes A Rush of Far-Right Initiatives
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu needed the support of far-right factions to return to the prime minister’s office. Now they want to curb the powers of the judiciary, giving rise to fears about an erosion of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister designate, is preparing to swear in his new right-wing government.

item.title: At France’s Oldest Christmas Market, Energy Crisis Dims Festive Spirits
item.description: Amid soaring gas prices and the war in Ukraine, Strasbourg’s Christkindelsmärik, like holiday fairs across Europe, has faced a tough question: “How do you balance magic and responsibility?”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Waiter Shortage Hits London Restaurants After Brexit
item.description: Europeans used to flock to London for restaurant jobs. Now, with doors to migrants largely closed after Britain left the European Union, many establishments are becoming desperate.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Padella, in Shoreditch, East London. Restaurants across London are so short of staff that many have curtailed their hours.

item.title: Nepali Court Orders the Release of Charles Sobhraj From Prison
item.description: The action trims the life sentence Charles Sobhraj, known as ‘the Serpent,’ who targeted Western tourists in Asia in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Charles Sobhraj, a French killer known as “the Serpent,” arriving for a court hearing in Bhaktapur, Nepal, in 2014.

item.title: Putin Concedes Military Failings, but Insists Russia Will Fight On
item.description: Nodding to criticism that his army lacked the basic necessities to wage war, the Russian leader said his government was providing “everything that the army asks for.’’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu, left, on Wednesday said, “The country and the government are providing everything that the army asks for — everything.”

item.title: 8 Teenage Girls Charged With Fatally Stabbing a Toronto Man
item.description: The police said the girls, who ranged from 13 to 16 years old, connected on social media before meeting up, possibly for the first time, on the day of the killing.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The corner of York St. and University Ave. in downtown Toronto, where the police said 8 teenage girls killed a man on Sunday.

item.title: President López Obrador Suggests the Attack on Ciro Gómez Leyva Was Staged
item.description: After assailants shot at Ciro Gómez Leyva in his own neighborhood, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador suggested that the assassination attempt was actually an effort to destabilize the government.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Germán Espinosa/Agencia EL UNIVERSAL/GDA via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ciro Gómez Leyva, a leading Mexican news anchor, was attacked by gunmen last week while driving through his neighborhood.

item.title: Dark Christmas Signals Tough Times for a Prosperous City in Hungary
item.description: Dimmed festive lighting at an annual market in the city of Gyor underscores the economic pain being felt across Hungary as energy costs and inflation soar.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Embarrassed after a call for residents to decorate the city themselves, the government of Gyor, Hungary, suddenly announced it had found money to string up some Christmas lights — though not as many as usual.

item.title: Taliban Bar Women From College Classes in Afghanistan
item.description: The new Afghan government has returned to its hard-line stances from the 1990s, instituting public beatings and executions as well further restricting women’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women leaving the campus of Kabul University on the first day of examinations in August.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Times Investigation Into Bucha
item.description: Also, Benjamin Netanyahu is poised to lead Israel again and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Xi Xi, Whose Writing Defined a Changing Hong Kong, Dies at 85
item.description: Her work captured the unease of Hong Kong’s transition to Chinese rule, gave voice to the city’s children and working-class residents, and helped put it on the literary map.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: The author Xi Xi at her home in Hong Kong with one of the teddy bears she started making as physical therapy after cancer treatment, dressing them as figures from Chinese mythology, literature and history.

item.title: Germany Arrests a Suspected Russian Spy Inside Its Intelligence Agency
item.description: The suspect, a German citizen, is being charged with treason. He is accused of passing state secrets to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon

item.title: Oscar White Muscarella, Museum ‘Voice of Conscience,’ Dies at 91
item.description: An archaeologist at the Met, he warned about plundered and fake antiquities and about the acquisition practices of collectors and museums, including his own.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Lukashenko Speaks on Belarus’s Military Moves and Ukraine War
item.description: Some Ukrainian officials have warned that a military exercise involving Russia could be a precursor to a new offensive aimed at Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus during a joint military exercise with Russian forces a week before Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine in February.

item.title: Zelensky Brings His Olive Green Sweatshirt to Congress
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine came to Washington wearing his reality on his sleeves.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Speaker Nancy Pelosi holding a Ukrainian flag signed by members of that country’s military. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine presented the flag to them when he addressed Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Oversight
item.description: After years of evading congressional investigators, Donald Trump is taking hits.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump.

item.title: For Zelensky, a Celebration of Resilience and a Sales Pitch for Support
item.description: For all the talk of victory, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s remarks in Washington revealed hints about his worries for the year ahead.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky receiving a standing ovation as he addressed the U.S. Congress in a joint session at the Capitol in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is the Polar Vortex? And Other Cold-Weather Climate Questions
item.description: As much of the United States plunges into a deep freeze, scientists continue to debate how rapid Arctic warming is playing a role.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Source: Climate Reanalyzer, Climate Change Institute at the University of Maine, using forecasts from the National Centers for Environmental Prediction Global Forecast System.

item.title: Caught on Camera, Traced by Phone: The Russian Military Unit That Killed Dozens in Bucha
item.description: Exclusive evidence obtained in a monthslong investigation identifies the Russian regiment — and commander — behind one of the worst atrocities in Ukraine.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Ukrainian leader sought to convey the reality of the war to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Bakhmut, the site of one of the bloodiest campaigns of the war, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky visited President Biden in his first known trip outside Ukraine since Russia invaded.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi hoist a Ukrainian flag signed by soldiers in the midst of war as Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky addresses a joint session of Congress.

item.title: Day 22: A Very Bollywood Christmas Playlist
item.description: Like many families only one generation removed from the “old country,” an Indian American writer’s family puts its own imprint on this omnipresent holiday.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Yasmin Marikar

item.title: Biden and Zelensky Present a United Front Against Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky described military assistance for Ukraine as an investment in global security and democracy in the face of Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Speaker Nancy Pelosi hold a Ukrainian flag signed by soldiers on the front line, delivered by President Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Zelensky’s Message: Ukraine Is Fighting for Good Over Evil
item.description: One of the Ukrainian leader’s overriding aims is to prevent support for the war from becoming a partisan issue.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Coalition Deal Puts Netanyahu on Brink of Power in Israel
item.description: After weeks of talks, Benjamin Netanyahu said he had formed a new governing coalition. Once ratified by Parliament, the deal will return him to power at the head of a hard-right alliance.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, has succeeded in forming a coalition government that is set to bring him back to power at the helm of the most right-wing administration in Israeli history.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Zelensky at the White House
item.description: Also, Donald Trump’s tax returns show losses during his presidency.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky went to Washington after visiting Ukraine’s eastern front.

item.title: What Are Patriot Missiles, and Why Does Ukraine Want Them?
item.description: The United States is sending its most advanced ground-based missile defense system to Ukraine, as Russia continues to pummel the country with airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Patriot antimissile system launcher in Rzeszow, Poland, in March.

item.title: As Ukraine Prepares for a Second Year at War, the Prospect of a Stalemate Looms
item.description: American officials believe that with Russia bolstering defenses and learning lessons, Ukraine will find it more challenging to retake land.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military has been reliant on American intelligence reports that pinpoint where the Russian Army is at its weakest.

item.title: Putin Vows ‘No Limits’ to Russia’s War Spending
item.description: The Russian leader’s speech to defense officials was his latest effort to show he has no intention of giving up in the war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: At a gathering of senior military officials, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia approved an increase of more than 300,000 troops for the country’s armed forces.

item.title: Hospitalizing the Homeless
item.description: New York City’s struggle to get severely mentally ill people off the streets.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: An encampment in Brooklyn this year.

item.title: UK Ambulance Workers Stage Their Largest Strike in Decades
item.description: The industrial action, seeking higher pay and better working conditions, was driven by a cost-of-living crisis and coincides with strikes by rail workers, nurses and others.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ambulance workers picketing outside the London Ambulance Service, a National Health Service agency, on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Ally Meets With China’s Top Leader, Signaling Close Ties
item.description: China has remained a significant, if largely silent, counterweight to the international censure of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, third from left, met with Dmitri A. Medvedev, the former Russian president and prime minister, center right, in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Electric Cars Are Taking Off, but When Will Battery Recycling Follow?
item.description: Many companies and investors are eager to recycle batteries, but it could take a decade or more before enough used lithium-ion batteries become available.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Reynaga unscrewing the main lithium battery from a vehicle at LKQ’s plant in Adelanto, Calif.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Edinburgh
item.description: Edinburgh calls to readers, its pearl-grey skies urging them to curl up with a book. Maggie O’Farrell, the author of “Hamnet,” suggests reading that best reflects her city.
item.dc:creator: Maggie O’Farrell
item.category: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (Book)

item.title: Zelensky Will Meet With Biden in Washington and Address Congress, Officials Say
item.description: The visit will be the first time President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has left his country since Russia invaded in February.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is set to discuss American military assistance with President Biden during his visit.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: As the war in Ukraine enters its 11th month, Volodymyr Zelensky is planning to address Congress in person today.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is set to accept American military assistance from President Biden during his visit.

item.title: Gunman in Vaughan Condo Shooting Was Being Forced Out of Building
item.description: The police on Tuesday identified the five people killed in a shooting one day before the gunman was scheduled to appear in court on orders to sell his unit.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The condominium building in Vaughan, a city north of Toronto, where five people were killed by a resident on Sunday.

item.title: Congress Proposes More Than $44 Billion for Ukraine
item.description: The spending bill unveiled Tuesday includes billions more for the country than President Biden had requested.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine on Sunday. A new U.S. spending bill would devote more than $44 billion in emergency aid for the country.

item.title: Taliban Release 2 Americans Detained in Afghanistan
item.description: One of the Americans being held is an independent filmmaker who had been held since August.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: A Taliban celebration in August on the anniversary of the United States withdrawal from Afghanistan.

item.title: 33 Pakistani Taliban Militants Killed After Holding Prison Hostage
item.description: The attack at a detention center in northwestern Pakistan is the latest in a resurgence in violence from Pakistani Taliban militants in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Security officials guarded a road leading to a counterterrorism center after security forces started to clear a compound seized by Pakistani Taliban militants in Bannu.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Zelensky Visits Bakhmut
item.description: Also, Japan’s central bank eases its policy and Fiji prepares for a leadership change.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service shows President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Bakhmut on Tuesday.

item.title: Lauding Their Soldiers, Putin and Zelensky Signal Long Fight Ahead
item.description: As the 10-month mark of the war nears, the leaders of Ukraine and Russia handed out medals and pledged not to back down.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine gave medals on Tuesday to his soldiers in Bakhmut, in a photo made available by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service.

item.title: Congress Offers $1 Billion for Climate Aid, Falling Short of Biden’s Pledge
item.description: Activists called the funding to help developing countries cope with the impacts of climate change “hugely disappointing.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The $1 billion falls far short of the billions President Biden had pledged to international climate change spending.

item.title: At a Holiday Celebration in Southern Ukraine, ‘Kids Still Need Miracles.’
item.description: Some asked Saint Nicholas for iPhones. Some asked for peace.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yevhen Vorobyov dressed as Saint Nicholas for a Christmas celebration in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: World Cup Homecoming Brings Argentina to a Halt
item.description: Millions of fans thronged the streets of Buenos Aires to welcome home Argentina’s national team in what may be the biggest open-air party in the capital’s history.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: UK Strikes: Nurses, Emergency Responders and Rail Workers Walk Out
item.description: Continuing strikes over pay and economic conditions are likely to disrupt travel and services during the holiday season. Here’s what to expect.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: National Health Service nurses went on strike Tuesday. The union that represents them is seeking a 19 percent pay increase.

item.title: In Fiji’s Election, One Former Coup Leader Displaces Another
item.description: The return of Sitiveni Rabuka paves the way for a potential pivot in a country where the United States and China are fighting for influence.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Sitiveni Rabuka, center, leaving a meeting in Suva, the capital of Fiji, on Tuesday. He is in line to take over as the country’s leader for the first time since 1999.

item.title: Boat With at Least 160 Rohingya Refugees Is Stranded at Sea
item.description: The U.N. called on countries in South Asia to rescue those on the vessel, who have been without food for weeks after leaving Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Karan Deep Singh
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: In November, another group of Rohingya refugees landed in a wooden boat in North Aceh, Indonesia.

item.title: EPA Tightens Rules on Pollution From Vans, Buses and Trucks
item.description: For the first time in decades, the agency has restricted nitrogen dioxide emissions from heavy vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: The rule will require heavy-duty trucks to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide 48 percent by 2045.

item.title: 1922: Last War Prisoners Gone
item.description: France released its last five German prisoners four years after World War I came to an end.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: U.S. Commandos Capture Six ISIS Officials in Raids in Syria
item.description: The operations were the second time in recent weeks that U.S. forces had killed or captured ISIS terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. forces patrolling in northern Syria on Thursday near a rehabilitation center for the children of suspected Islamic State members.

item.title: Trump’s Culpability
item.description: The House Jan. 6 committee placed clear blame on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack met yesterday.

item.title: Zelensky Visits Bakhmut, Aiming To Show Ukraine’s Resolve
item.description: Despite months of Russian bombardments and waves of assaults, the city has remained in Ukrainian control.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service shows President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Bakhmut on Tuesday.

item.title: Kyiv Has Power for a Fifth of Residents After Repeated Russian Attacks
item.description: “Ten hours without electricity in Kyiv is, unfortunately, a new reality,” the head of the local utility said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family in front of St. Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv during a power outage on Saturday.

item.title: German Court Sentences Ex-Concentration Camp Secretary to Probation
item.description: Irmgard Furchner, who was in her late teens when she worked in the Stutthof camp, was convicted as the authorities make a final effort to seek justice for Nazi-era crimes.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Irmgard Furchner had asked to be tried in absentia, but the judge in Itzehoe, in northern Germany, ordered her to appear.

item.title: China’s Abrupt Covid Pivot Leaves Many Without Medicines
item.description: Millions are desperate to get their hands on fever-reducing drugs and antivirals such as Pfizer’s Paxlovid as infections across China outpace supplies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Isabelle Qian, Olivia Wang and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buying medicine at a pharmacy in Beijing on Tuesday. Medication has flown off drugstore shelves across China as signs of outbreaks of Covid have emerged.

item.title: As Tunisia Drifts Farther From Democracy, Voters Shun Election
item.description: Turnout in Saturday’s parliamentary elections was just over 11 percent, reflecting deep skepticism that politics can solve the North African nation’s grave governmental and economic crises.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ahmed Ellali
item.media:description: Tunisia’s electoral board president, Farouk Bouasker, announcing the preliminary results of the parliamentary elections on Monday in the capital, Tunis. Just over 11 percent of eligible voters cast ballots.
